---
title: 'Recovery from work: testing the effects of chronic internal and external workload
  on health and well-being'
type: pub
encoding: UTF-8

---
<h1>Publication</h1>
<article id="csl-bib-container-RZ726V3F" class="csl-bib-container">
  <div class="csl-bib-body"> <div class="csl-entry">Cropley, M., Rydstedt, L. W., &#38; Andersen, D. (2020). Recovery from work: testing the effects of chronic internal and external workload on health and well-being. <i>Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health</i>, <i>74</i>(11), 919–924. <a href="https://doi.org/10.1136/jech-2019-213367">https://doi.org/10.1136/jech-2019-213367</a></div> </div>

<div id="csl-bib-meta-RZ726V3F" class="csl-bib-meta">
  <article id="about-article-RZ726V3F" class="about_pub-article">
    <h1>About</h1>
    Cropley et al. conducted a study to understand how ongoing high workloads affect health and well-being. They used survey data from Norwegian workers collected in 2013 and 2016. The study looked at internal workload (like having too much to do at work and skipping lunch breaks) and external workload (using mobile technology for work during leisure time). They found that people with consistently high internal workload reported more psychological and physical fatigue, as well as sleep problems. High external workload was linked to psychological and physical fatigue, but less strongly. This research highlights the importance of managing work demands to prevent long-term health issues like fatigue and sleep disturbances.
  </article>
  <article id="keywords-article-RZ726V3F" class="keywords-article">
    <h1>Keywords</h1>
    Workload, Health, Well-being, Psychological Fatigue, Physical Fatigue, Sleep Problems
  </article>
  <article id="abstract-article-RZ726V3F" class="abstract-article">
    <h1>Scientific abstract</h1>
    The aim of this study was to examine the effects of reduced recovery opportunities on health, associated with chronic internal workload (ie, during work) and external workload (ie, following work).MethodsData from two consecutive surveys (2013 and 2016) from the Norwegian Living Conditions Survey on Work Environment were used. To assess a dose–response association between workload and health, self-reported ratings of internal workload (ie, having too much to do and skipping lunch breaks during work) and external workload (ie, using mobile technology for work-related issues during leisure time) over the two time periods were divided into tertile groups representing low, medium and high workload. Anxiety, depression, physiological and psychological fatigue and sleep were assessed as outcome symptoms.ResultsChronic medium levels of internal workload were associated with psychological fatigue (OR=2.84, 95% CI 1.75 to 4.62) and physical fatigue (OR=1.85, 95% CI 1.31 to 2.63), and high internal workload was associated with psychological fatigue (OR=7.24, 95% CI 4.59 to 11.40), physical fatigue (OR=4.23, 95% CI 3.06 to 5.83) and sleep problems (OR=1.81, 95% CI 1.07 to 3.05). Chronic external high workload was only associated with psychological fatigue (OR=1.67, 95% CI 1.26 to 2.22) and with physical fatigue problems (OR=1.47, 95% CI,1.09–1.98) when the data were adjusted for age, gender, education level, job autonomy and occupational status.ConclusionsThis study emphasises that individuals who chronically experience high workload are at an increased risk for reporting psychological and physical fatigue, and sleep problems.
  </article>
